Gentlemen, your final question comes from the line of Paul Newsome representing Sandler O'Neill Partners. Please proceed.

Thank you. Good morning. I was hoping you could spend just a little bit more time on the auto frequency results. And particularly it looks like many folks assume that the frequency trend would continue to be favorable. What's your view on that topic? And do you think at some point in time we start getting negative frequency trends and see some price increases as a result of inflation at your firm?

Well, what we've seen is that loss frequency for the last, if you look over the last ten years, had a significant decline, and we are near historic lows from an absolute frequency perspective. So it wouldn't surprise us if we saw those frequency numbers climb a little bit. And when you measure frequency trend, that's, of course, the change from period over period. So picking up a little bit could see some positive trend but still be near historic lows. We're seeing a little bit of increase in frequency in the last several quarters. It's not at alarming rates, alarming rates of growth. And we project when we project forward total loss trend and project total loss trend to be in the low to mid-single digits, and that's what we think about through our environment over the next year and which is incorporated in our underlying guidance. We don't usually break that apart when we're disclosing it between frequency and severity, because sometimes those move counter to each other. We -- so it's really more appropriate to project them in aggregate.

Independent of the mix change -- which we are trying to highlight on page 22; obviously page 21 shows a modest increase in frequency -- it's very difficult to look out and predict with any thoughtfulness what's going to happen. You're talking about everything from numbers of miles driven to the impact of fuel and seatbelt usage and cell phone usage and changing state laws that prohibit, that require hands-free cell phones. There's so many variables that go into frequency. I don't think that we particularly have any great insight into why something would change. And again that's independent of the mix dynamic on page 22.
Are you pricing for low single-digit claims inflation currently?
The guidance that we provided anticipates that running through the environment.
Yeah, but I guess that's not the question. The question is whether or not you're pricing for it in your policies.
Again, our pricing...

Yeah, let's back up for a moment. We provide and have at our investor days given insight into the recurrence that we're recording in our businesses, and as it relates to the Personal Lines business broadly and particularly, it's well within the targeted returns of the business. If you're asking how we price a particular product in a particular market, it's a very complicated question. We look for the returns on a book of business overall, and the book of business continues to meet our target thresholds. We're pricing it to do that. I'm not sure how to exactly answer that question. But we're pricing the product to achieve our targeted returns.

We look at targeted returns. We look at the marketplace dynamics. We look at opportunities for growth. And we look at what we expect will be the underlying loss trend, and we put them all together. We don't take any one of those variables independently and solely make a price change on that. We're not trying to dodge the question. You've got to take all four, five of those things and mix them together.

Again, what we said we priced the product achieve our targeted returns given everything we see happening in the marketplace. So a silly assumption would be that we price it to achieve targeted returns assuming a decrease in loss trend. We are not assuming a decrease in loss trend. We are essentially assuming that loss trend will continue at low single digits. And that's how we price our product.
I think we're all just trying to figure out if auto has bottomed out industry-wide. And there's certain mixed results from various companies.

I don't have a comment I can make on industry-wide dynamics. Page 21 is giving you very specific insight into our book, and you can see that our loss trend has been running for the last several quarters in the low-single-digit total loss trend, and that's how we're pricing our product.
Yeah, and gentlemen as well, thank you for the increased disclosure. That's indeed very helpful.
Pleasure.
Gentlemen, there are no further questions at this time. I would now like to turn the call back to Mr. Connelly for closing remarks.
Thanks very much for taking the time today to discuss what was a terrific 2007. If anybody has comments or questions, please feel free to follow up with me directly. Thanks.
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation in today's conference. This concludes your presentation. You may now disconnect. Good day.
